lines.text: Next to a battle lost, the saddest thing is a battle won.
Never interrupt your enemy while he's making a mistake. That's bad manners.
By God, Sir. I've lost my leg.
By God, Sir. So you have.
I know you loved this man.
I did, once. But I promise you, that I will bring him back to Paris in an iron cage.
[exits]
How they exaggerate, these soldiers, "In an iron cage"? Nobody asked for that.

[clears throat]
Sir.

[removing his copy of The Times from over his face]
Ah, Uxbridge.
As I am second-in-command and in case anything should happen to you, what are your plans?
To beat the French.
[goes back to sleep, replacing the newspaper]
The whole line will advance.
In which direction your grace?
Why, straight ahead to be sure.
[Historical quote]

[referring to his army]
I don't know what they'll do to the enemy; but, by God, they frighten me.
[Observing the advance of the Gordon Highlanders]
Has Wellington nothing to offer me but these Amazons?

[wounded on his horse]
The Prussians are in the woods! Blucher is in the woods!
I made one mistake in my life; I should have burned Berlin.
Cross the river. Tomorrow we will dry our boots in Brussels.
God willing, sire.
God? God has nothing to do with it.
[Napoleon is watching the charge of the Scots Greys]
Those men on grey horses are terrifying.
They are the noblest cavalry in Europe; and the worst led.
That may be; that may be, but we will match them with our lancers.

[on Napolean's maneuver that split the English and Prussian armies]
By God, that man does war honor.
Wellington's on the run! I caught him at Quatre Bras! He's retreating!
If Wellington's retreating, what are you doing here?
But, Sire...
If Wellington's retreating, what are you doing here? Why didn't you follow him? Why didn't you pursue?

[Raises voice]
where are the reinforcements you promised me?

[shouting]
Don't you dare criticize me! Don't you dare! Don't you see if Wellington's free to choose his ground then everything I've won in this campaign you've lost!

[watching the advance of troops in the distance]
Prussians.
[Ney aims his own telescope]
That is not necessary, that is not necessary. They're Prussians, but as far as the army's concerned, they're on the moon. Understand?
Well they've done it! The whole of Europe has declared war against me! Not against France, but against me.
They dignify you sire by making you a Nation!

[laughing]
Dignify? Dignify? They deny me the decency of law! They make it legal that any clown can kill me.
Well we've fought with mud in our boots before!
Yes well, I'll discuss peace over Wellington's dead body, that's my peace table!
Le Bedoyere, do you have any children?
Yes, sire; one son, very young,no taller than your boot.
And if he were with you, would you want him with you here today?
Yes, sire.
Yes, why?
So he could see you, sire.
See me? You know, I have a son. I'd give anything in the world to see him. I'd give my heart, I'd give my life, but not here. I wouldn't want him to witness this battle here today.
When I am dead and gone what will the world say of me?
They'll say that you extended the limits of glory, sire.
The limits of glory'; is that all I have to leave to my son, the 'limits of glory'?
[On Wellington's refusal to move]
caution, and above all, courage
[speaks up]
He hasn't moved, he's nailed himself to his ridge. Now's the time to move all the heavy artillery against Picton.

[after the defeat of the Prussians at Ligny]
The field of honor is never a pretty sight. Nevertheless, sixteen thousand Prussian dead; that's good news to slap on the walls in Paris, eh?

[to Blucher on Wellington's request to move in the direction of Waterloo]
If Wellington runs to the coast, none of us will make it home to Berlin. I do not trust the English, nonetheless because I have served you before, sir...

[Disgusted with Gneisenau]
I am seventy-two and a proud soldier. This sword is steel! I am too old to break it.
Very well, I have ordered the retreat to Wavre. You may still co-operate with the Wellington, but God help us if he does not stand.

[to the Duchess of Richmond about arranging the ball]
You really are the best of my generals.
I can't believe my ears! You all stand before me waving a piece of paper crying 'Abdicate, abdicate!' I WILL NOT! I WILL NOT, NOT, NOT!
Good beans, Wellington!
If there is anything in this world about which I know positively nothing, it is agriculture.
We're doing murder, your grace.
I hope to God... that I've fought my last battle.
[the Prussians are preparing to attack]
Raise high the black flags, my children. No prisoners. No pity. I will shoot any man I see with pity in him.
[before the battle starts, the British troops are singing a mocking song about Napoleon]
Shall I shut them up, Sir?
No, no, indulge it . Anything that wastes time is good. Indulge it. Normally I don't like cheering, but there's always a time to cut cards with the Devil.
Bylandt's's brigade has broken. Plug the gap, if you please.
Gordon, get your bastards up on to the crest. I'll bring up the rest of the brigade.
Don't hurry yourself, Pic. My lads will hold them, aye, 'til you come.
Get forward, damn your eyes!
My Father poor fellow, was killed by the French. Never should have happened
Really?
Yes, his horse got caught in a bog and the brute just gave up. Seven damn lancers had him like a tiger in a pit. Bad luck, eh, Uxbridge?
Damn bad luck!
Mama, Iggy has promised to bring me a cuirassier's helmet to use as a work basket - without blood in it, Mama.
And one for me, young man - *with* the blood.
And where do you plan to stick your Frenchman, Hay?
I thought under the right arm, sir.
See? He has it all planned.
When you meet a cuirassier beam-to-beam, you'll be lucky if you bring away your life with you, never mind his helmet. Boy, you'll learn the art of fighting from the French.
[the French artillery has begun firing on the English positions]
Well, that opens the ball.
They're coming on in the same old style.
Well, then we shall have to meet them in the same old style.
[referring to the English troops]
They're the salt of England, Arthur.
Scum. Nothing but beggars and scoundrels, all of them. Gin is the spirit of their patriotism.
Yet you expect them to die for you?
Um-hum.
Out of duty?
Um-hum.
I doubt if even Bonaparte could draw men to him by duty.
Oh, Boney's not a gentleman.
Arthur! What an Englishman you are.
On the field of battle his hat is worth fifty thousand men; but he is not a gentleman.

[the Old Guard is surrounded by British cavalry]
Brave Frenchmen! You have done all that the honor of war demands; His Grace, the Duke of Wellington, invites you to save your lives! Will you surrender?
MERDE!
[Cavalry pulls back exposing ranks of artillery]

[in pain from the early stages of stomach cancer]
My body is dying, but my mind is still good!
He's commiting Reille's Division now sir, he intends to turn us, on the right!
What the master does and what he intends are as different as white knight to black bishop.
We could quickly move the 95th down, sir.
I do not intend to run around like a wet hen! There'll be plenty of time, sir.
Before we go, Uxbridge...
[proffering snuff powder]

[snorts]
Ah...
[sneezes]
Savage stuff, Ponsonby!
You don't see its like any more. My father left us a hundredweight, down to the last ounce. An old Jew in Alexandria had the blend.
Blend?
[Ponsonby laughs]
[Bonaparte is facing down Louis XVIII's artillery, unarmed]
Soldiers of the fifth. Do you recognise me?
[pause]
If you want to kill your Emperor? Here I am.
...this year, soldiers are the fashion.

[ironically]
Where would society be without my boys?

[as elite French soldiers retreat in disorder]
Are you France? Are you the Guard?
General Picton doesn't know how to walk in a ballroom.
But he is very good when he is dancing with the French.
If Blucher doesn't show up here soon, he'll break every bone in my body!

What's he doing? What's Ney doing? What's happening? Can't I leave the field for a minute? What's he doing there? How can a man go forward with the cavalry without infantry support? What's the matter with you?
[as the British cavalry charge across the battlefield]
Sound the recall!
[a trumpeter blows the signal on his trumpet. The cavalry either ignore or can't hear it, continuing to charge towards the French cannon. The trumpeter keeps sounding]

[irritably]
Stop that useless noise!
[kinder]
You'll hurt yourself.

[dictating a letter]
To my dear Prince Alexis... I did not "usurp" the crown. I found it, in the gutter, and I, I picked it up with my sword, and it was the people, Alexis, the people who put it on my head. He who saves a nation violates no law.
